newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Malaysia Malacca refinery runs at 121,000 bpd.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia Malacca refinery runs at 121,000 bpd.

text.p: Malaysia's state-owned oil company Petronas is now running its refinery in Malacca at 121,000 barrels per day (bpd), back to its operating rate before a recent nationwide power blackout, sources said on Friday.
The operating rate is about 20 percent over the refinery's nameplate capacity of 100,000 bpd.
The refinery was shutdown for about four days to a week after the blackout on August 3. It was gradually restored to 115,000 bpd by mid-August.

But the refinery, which is located on the east coast of Peninsula Malaysia, was again shut for a day on August 16 due to technical problems at the crude distillation unit and was subsequently restored to its pre-blackout running rate.
Sources said the refinery has been running at around 120,000 bpd over the past two months prior to the power outage.
The refinery processes domestic light sweet Tapis crude and condensates from Bintulu.
A power trip at the Paka power plant in the east coast state of Terengganu prompted all other power plants in the country to shut down as a precaution and so affected the Malacca refinery.
